title: Man, 24, dies after collapsing at Montreal Marathon | CBC News
text:
A 24-year-old man has died after he collapsed on Sunday during the Montreal Marathon event, according to the Quebec coroner's office.

Patrick Neely, 24, was running the half-marathon when he collapsed near the corner of Cherrier and St-Hubert streets at around 10 a.m.

He was about two kilometres from the finish line when he went into cardiac arrest, authorities say.

Urgences-Santé spokesperson Valérie Tremblay said when first responders arrived, bystanders were performing CPR on the man.

The race's first aid teams were not yet on the scene, she said.

Ambulance workers then took over and transported the victim to hospital in critical condition.

8-minute response time

Tremblay said Urgences-Santé was notified of the collapsed runner at 9:55 a.m. First responders, including ambulance workers, arrived on-site at 10:03 a.m.

As part of the event, she said Urgences-Santé had been collaborating with organizers to make sure ambulances could respond quickly to emergencies.

Race organizers post first aid teams along the route and ambulances are stationed nearby to assist when notified. She was unable to say who called 911.

Other than the usual traffic, she said, there were no major delays in getting an ambulance, already on standby, to the scene Sunday morning.

"We know how this event works so we are prepared for those kinds of things," she told Daybreak on Monday.

Rock 'n' Roll Montreal Marathon race director Dominique Piché told CBC he would not provide more information until organizers had more details of what happened.

He said his focus is on the family of the victim at this time and he is offering them his condolences.
description: A runner who collapsed at this weekend's half-marathon in Montreal has died, according to the Quebec coroner's office.
